description.text:
Well, not paper, exactly, but you get the idea!

So, I'd had this idea of making a print that would unfold after printing, into a chain much longer than the original build size, and the snowflake seemed an excellent place to try that! There were some challenges - read on!

But first, what is this?

So, this is an entry in the BlocksCAD snowflake contest, which means that the model was created entirely from code written in BlocksCAD. What's more, it's constructed in a parameterised way, so that things like the number of snowflakes in the chain can be altered, and a new model produced automatically.

But yes, a paper chain! The chain prints folded, standing up, in a compact box shape. It's entirely assembled, with hinges ready to swivel and unfold.

Challenges

Most obviously, the hinge is the tricky thing, here. Now, a hinge isn't a difficult thing to design, even one that prints in-place like this. Where the tricky bit comes in is making an offset hinge printable despite being in mid-air.
If you take a look at the model, you'll see that the hinge is all made up of angles that slope upwards, and horizontals are avoided. What might be less obvious is that the hinge strut that extends from the snowflake body to the bottom of the hinge pin not only supports the pin for printing, but prevents the upper hinge pin attachment from taking too much force if there's friction in the hinge. I have to say, I really had a lot of fun designing this :D

Visual design considerations

I originally had the snowflake panel much more complicated, but it really detracted from the overall chain. So, I kept it simple, bold, and iconic, and the chain looks much more coherent as a result.
However! If you want to fiddle with the snowflake panel in the code, it's all managed by the "build snowflake core" module, so it's easy to do!

Where to from here?

Well, beyond this particular snowflake thing, there's plenty of scope to extend this to different shapes, and to customise the sequence of flakes with letters to form messages - cheesy Valentines heart chain messages, here I come! Have fun :)

Printer:

Witbox 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Notes:

This print will test your bridging! The snowflake detail has some decent horizontal action going on, so make sure you're on point with your cooling! Really, though, there's nothing too scary in there, and the structure is pretty robust in general.

If you're concerned about layer adhesion, since each snowflake is essentially an independent, if linked, part, consider putting an 8mm brim on the print.

I actually found that 0.2mm layer height worked well, and 0.1mm was a bit tricky, probably due to the bridging. I'm going to pull out a 1.0mm nozzle and give it a run at some point with a drastically greater layer height!

description.text:
This is a simple 1 axis desk stand for cameras. You can mount actioncams, small DSLR cameras (~600gram), microphones or your mobile phone onto it.

I like to use it if i want to film solder work, for this it works quite nice.

You will need 1 M3 screw with nut for the camera mount. The mobile mount needs 2 additional M3 screws and nuts.

The 2 slider parts for the mobilephone need to be screwed together in a distance where you phone will snap in.

I have printed it with PLA at 0.4mm layerheight using 45% infill. Also i recommend using at least 2 shells.

If you need camera screws, have a look at this awesome cusomziable thingi by stylesuxx ->
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2749041

Have fun and let me know if you have ideas to improve it :)

Update:

  • i reduced the distance between the mount rings, to be able to tighten the screw a bit better.
  • added model for a tpu antislide mount - @stylesuxx thanks for the feedback :)

title: Prusa i3 MK2/MK3 External Ventilator Cover

description.text:
Extruder ventilator on Prusa i3 slightly whirls the air on suction side of the extruder, which resolves in unintended cooling of one side of printed objects. When printing (especially with ABS), this can lead to worse bed adhesion of the object on this side.

This fan cover blocks the air going down toward heatbed. The MK3 version also masks the color of the ventilator a bit.

The MK2 version is mounted with screws that holds the ventilator.
The MK3 version just snaps on the ventilator (no screws needed, holds very well on spot).

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Recommended print settings (Prusa Slic3r):
ABS/PET (dont use PLA - it is too close to extruder and heatbed)
Perimeters: 2-3
0.2 layer hight
Auto cooling: ON

MK3 version:
Must be printed with support!
Detect bridging: ON

*Presliced GCODE for MK3 is included (ABS, 0.2 layer height).

Update 1

Added new MK3 version (ver2) which can be printed without any support and also covers bottom of the fan.

* Special thanks to RiDDLeRN for this idea.

description.text:
This is a stand for my sons lego minifigures.
You need some wood pieces from homedepot with 40mm x 13mm or 30mm x 13mm; Lenght is variable like 900mm or 1000mm. There are side parts for both variants.

Best is to print the parts laying on the printerbed.

Print 2 sideparts (L+R), drill some holes (with a dremel or something like that), put the wood pieces in and tighten. I decided not to print the wholes because everyone has other screws at the garage :) or maybe you would like to glue the wood in.

For the Figure-Base at the wood i used: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:742152
(2 row ones; connected with 2-side tape to the wood)

If you want, the stair could be stacked with the connection parts. I need 2 ones because of my printing size with 210x210.

-------------- German
Dies ist ein Figurenständer den ich für meinen Sohn und seine Lego Minifiguren gemacht habe.
Es werden aus dem Baumarkt noch Holzlatten in 40mm x 13mm oder 30mm x 13mm gebraucht. Die Länge ist beliebig, meist gibt es 900mm oder 1m. Es sind für beide Varianten Seitenteile verfügbar und können kombiniert werden (Stapeln)

Einfach 2 passende Seitenteile (L+R) drucken (am besten liegend auf dem Druckerbett), Löscher bohren (kann auch eingeklebt werden), Latten einlegen und befestigen. Ich habe beschlossen die Löscher nicht zu drucken da jeder andere Schrauben in der Garage hat oder eventuell jemand auch einkleben will.

Für die Minifiguren auf der Holzlatte habe ich diesen genutzt: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:742152 (2er Reihen mit doppelseitigen Klebeband)

Wenn gewünscht können auch 2 Ständer übereinander montiert werden, Verbindungsteile sind vorhanden. Ich habe dieses geteilt wegen meiner Druckgröße von 210x210.

title: Sony Alpha Mirror Specchio Espejo a6000 a6300 a6500
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Screen solution for Sony Alpha camera Alpha series.
Works perfectly with Sony a6000, a6300 and a6500

This is a brilliant and affordable solution to monitor yourself with a Sony mirrorless camera. You don’t need an external monitor to check your focus or your composition.
This solution allows anyone to see what’s on the screen including the metadata and audio levels. Perfect for vloggers and preserves battery life.
The sony a6300 and a6500 are notorious because of their infamous overheating issues, the use of an external monitor or the remote screen from the playmemories app usually consumes more battery and ends up overheating the device.
With this custom mirror will not affect battery life in any way, the only downside would be the specular image and the metadata will be backwards.

Two small rubber supports to prevent any kind of scratch or damage to the camera body as well as to ensure a perfect fit and additional grip.

----- For Sony Alpha 6300: Cut off object BOTTOM: 8mm [Cura settings] -----

You also need:

A piece of mirror 5,7 x 6 mm ( x 3 mm thickness)
You probably will have to make a custom cut from a bigger mirror

2 Pieces: Rubber Bumpers: 10 x 3 mm

description.text:
A Doll's Pet Needs Care Too!

A friend of my daughter was coming over for a play date with her American Girl doll and her pet cat. A quick look and I didn't see anything quite to my satisfaction so I thought I would whip up one of my own!

Not just for American Girl dolls

Of course, there is nothing special about this dish when it comes to size - if you have a pet for an 18" doll, a small stuffed animal, or you want to play with the scale, you could make this for any of your stuffed animal pets!

BUT NOT FOR REAL PETS

A caution that this should not be used to hold actual food or water for a living pet. In general, you should never use any 3D printed items from a home printer to contain food or liquids for any living being. There are too many "what if" questions involved. Better to just buy a nice metal set for your pet that you care about!

That said, if you print this for your kid's stuffed animal (or a stuffed animal of yours!), please post your make - I'd love to see what you have done!

Cheers, and God Bless!

Dan the 3D Printing Dad

title: Creality CR-10 Upgrade Suite
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update!
Creality CR-10 Upgrade Suite.
This kit includes an extruder with improved ergonomics and functionality as well as an improved bed level adjustment system. New as of 1-25-18 is the inclusion of a E3D-V6 hot-end adapter. This adapter places the V6 nozzle at the same height as the stock CR-10 nozzle for ease of change over and no modification is needed for the z micro switch. It also holds the hot-end very solidly so there is no allowance for movement, it is designed to work with the "Fan Fang" cooling mod. This adapter requires (1x) M3x20 & (1x) M3x16 screw. The extruder is designed to run rubber filament, features an extended contoured release lever, a filament feed port which allows various feed angles and keeps the filament from contacting the z-screw. In addition it has a cable clip for the hot-end wire loom and is designed to be more easily serviced.
This kit also includes a bed level knob and pointer / keeper with improved ergonomics and functionality as well. The knob is numbered 0-9 with each location being 36 degrees apart. The pointer / keeper indicates the current position and keeps it from moving due to vibration and bed movement. The numbers can be used to note a position before adjusting and each tic on its index is equivalent to .019mm or .0008" in Z.
***Just a note, the models have all been re-oriented to drop into Cura with no rotational adjustment.

Creality CR-10

comments.text: Thank you for your feedback.  I would say check your print settings and quality if the part failed, also check that you didn't over-tighten the joint as the print model includes threads which are precise.  Beyond that all I can offer at this point is to give you some additional background on this design:  I have been using this mod on a CR-10 and a Ender II for several months without any problems.  I know of 4 others personally that use this on their CR-10's and Enders with no issues.    I have conducted real-world torture tests along with FEA tests to prove the joint besides practical use for months.  I will keep track of this feedback for future design revisions so again, thanks for the feedback.  I hope this is helpful, thanks for downloading.

This is a Pod for the Hyperlite floss 2 frame. If you want to use this thing, there are some parts you have to first think of:
-Your electronics stack can only be 26mm high
-you need to use a micro size camera
-it is recommended to use a linear antenna
-you need to be ok with removing the nuts under the standoffs in the back
-the cam angle only goes from 47 to 55, but you can melt or cut a bit of the plastic away to make room for another angle

To install this thing you need extra:
-2x m2x7mm screw
-2x m2 washer

Install:
First, put the cam in place. Then, use a washer and a m2x7mm screw to secure the camera on one side, then do the same thing on the other side. then tighten the screws to a point, where you still can move the cam up and down, but its sits tightly where it is.
Installing the pod in the front is simple: Just stick the pod on the 16mm screws and put a self tightening lock nut on it. in the back, just screw it on the standoffs. Finally, put your antenna through the little slot in the back, now it sits in place, has still space to move away when you hit something and can be easily replaced.

That should be it, now you can enjoy your nice looking, new pod.

remixed_from.author: Thebak3
remixed_from.title: XYZ Printing DaVinci PRO Door Switch Holder

title: XYZ Printing DaVinci 1.0 PRO Door Switch Holder - Leave In Place

description.text:
A quick remix of the oh-so-helpful XYZ Printing DaVinci PRO Door Switch Holder by Thebak3. Now you don't have to remove it to close the door!

Important: This installs upside-down (or bed-side up). It will not work the other way. Also, when installing, be sure to slide it in at an angle, with the front as far down as it will go, then slip the back over, otherwise the nub will end up above the button, and you will have to try again for it to work.

What I changed:

  • Trimmed down the inside of the back. I had to remove over a millimeter of material from the original to get it to fit, but this fit right off the build plate, after the usual trimming of imperfections, of course.
  • Reduced the width of the two side bars. I have a set of Hole Plugs installed, and with the original width it just barely scraped against the plug in that corner, so I trimmed 1mm off.
  • Significantly thinned the part that pushes the button. It is now thin enough that it doesn't interfere with normal operation of the door, so you can just pop it in and forget about it. I designed this part of it for printing at .3mm layer height, so it may not work if you print at a different height. I had to sand down the top of the thin portion, just enough to get rid of the roughness, for it to sit snugly.
  • Made the back part taller. It goes down to the floor inside the printer for added stability. I found that this makes it stay in place very well. Just in case you don't want that, I've included a "thin" version that doesn't have it.
  • Trimmed the button pusher. This version is more sensitive to orientation (it's designed to be installed with the ridge on the bottom), so I made the button-pushing nub smaller, now it won't push the button if installed upside-down. This change is less necessary in the thin version, but I kept it there for consistency.
  • Rounded some of the corners. Prints can be sharp. This one still is, but in fewer places.
  • Fought a deadly dinosaur invasion. I didn't have to, but it was fun, so I did it anyway. This likely had no effect on the model.
  • Converted the model to millimeters. Every slicer I've ever seen defaults to millimeters, so it just makes sense to model in them.

What I didn't change:

  • It holds down the door button for you. That's the only reason it was useful, why would I change it?
  • It does not hold down the top door button. I do want to change that though... maybe a future thing?
  • The conciseness of this thing's name. It's still ridiculously long.
  • The second law of thermodynamics. Unfortunately, this thing will not prevent the heat death of the universe, nor can it create infinite, free energy. Sorry.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

10% (doesn't really matter)

Notes:

I recommend sanding down the roughness on the top of the thin section, and adding a slight bevel to the bottom outside edge of the same, to help the tabs on the door slide up onto it if they happen to hit it. That didn't happen often for me, but the tolerances are tight and a small bevel is easy to add.

title: adxl345 and ESP8266 / LoLin g-force sensor

description.text:
This print takes a LoLin ESP8288 module along with an adxl345 g- force / acceleration sensor.
The sensor is tilted by 45° in all three axis. Like this, the accelerations measured in all axis can be combined to get a better resolution in z direction.
Goes together with a couple of M3 nuts and bolts.
ESP8266 and sensor Modul are "upside down" to directly use jumper wires.

Designed in Onshape;

  • UEW wire

remixed_from.title: UK40OB - Ultimate K40 Laser Cutter Upgrade

description.text:
Update 1/31/2018: The 24mm OD wheel kits available on Amazon are not compatible with this design. Also note, since the file was originally intended to be cut by laser or CNC, the tolerance for the joints are extremely tight. Printing the STLs unmodified will require a little work with a file to get things to fit. In the coming days, I'll upload another set of parts to accommodate the larger wheels I have and loosen the tolerances to more easily fit together.

This is a remix of Ariel Yahni's K40 conversion work. These parts are an alternative for the cut or milled parts from his work that can be printed on a Monoprice Select Mini. A BOM and build details will be provided as I complete the conversion. This project will require significant changes to the K40 electronics and housing.

title: Case for Raspberry Pi and Arduino Nano

description.text:
As case for a combined Raspberry Pi 3 and Arduino Nano project. Parts can be use separately (as case for only the Pi or the Arduino). In the Arduino case there is place for a custom PCB. The USBcable between the two chips is intended to be external as a connection, as I found it easier this way.

The nano and the custom PCB is intended to be mounted with a M3 4mm screw.4

The whole thing can be mounted to a wall or a table with 4 M3 screws. On top, the LEDs of both devices are visible from the outside.

Needs 8 x M3 screws for closing (for example 30mm long).

The original Sketchup 2016 file is also included, for further remixing.

title: Wii Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Want to mount your Wii to a wall? Try this.

About
I tried to create a wall mount for my Wii that is stable but where it's also easy to remove the console, so it could also be used to just store the console without eating up too much space (no idea why anyone would want this though).

It was also a criteria that the GameCube controller / memory card sockets stay accessible, which you can see in image 3.

This model does only work if you want your Wii on a left wall (from front view). If anyone would like a version for this, don't hesitate to leave a comment or write me a message.

Use whatever screw type (and maybe wall plugs) that fit your wall the best. I'm not responsible if your Wii falls off and gets damaged.

Only tested with the 2006 version of the Wii.

Other mounts for Nintendo consoles I designed:

  • Simple N64 Wall Mount
  • Simple GameCube Wall Mount
  • Wii Wall Mount

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

This model does only work if you want your Wii on a left wall. If anyone needs a right-wall-version, don't hesitate to leave a comment or send me a message.

Print with the wall facing part down and generate supports for the clamp.

Printed with a 0.4mm nozzle in PLA with 3 outlines.

Make sure that the mount is flat on the wall and there is no tension on the arm with the clamp when drilling the holes.

The screw holes in this model are for 3mm screws with a countersunk head.

title: Housing for Duet3D Laser Filament Monitor

description.text:
These are the printed parts for the Duet3D prototype Laser Filament Monitor described at https://duet3d.com/wiki/Duet3d_Filament_Monitor:_laser_version. They must be printed in black plastic. I suggest 0.2mm layer height.

You can use Customizer to adjust the height of the centre of the filament above the PCB for optimum detection by the laser. Choose a multiple of your layer height. We have not yet determined the optimum value for this, but 6mm seems to work well with 1.75mm filament.

You can also adjust the diameter of the hex clamp for the PTFE inlet and output tubes. 4.6mm is about right for 4mm OD PTFE tube.

title: Automata 1 Bill and Ben watering Flower

description.text:
I like to take a break from clocks over the Winter and try something different, so this year I have started to look at Automata, lots of wonderful designs out there but not that many taking advantage of 3D printing. I started with the idea of a flower raising its head to follow the Sun around the sky as they often do and developed that into this first model with three motions driven by simple cams.
This project has characters based on Bill and Ben the Flowerpot men, a popular puppet show on television in the 1950’s.
They have been changed a bit to suit building on a 3D printer and the original Weed character is now a Flower which has a flower head that is lifted when Bill pours water on it from his watering can.
For more details https://www.3dprinterclocks.com/page25.html

A sequel for the printable padlock: a locking box with a real locking mechanism and a sliding lid.
Uses the exact same locking mechanism as the padlock and is fully parametric.

Print a lock mechanism (mechanism body, bolt, tumblers and key) from the printable padlock item http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27205 and assemble it using the instructions there. Print the box and a lid, there's a solid lid and a slotted one for use as a piggy bank. Insert the mechanism into the compartment inside the box, bolt pointing upwards, slide the lid into place and turn the key 180 degrees counterclockwise to lock the box. The scad file contains in addition to the box, all the code for the lock mechanism and the padlock as well, so if you want custom keying (or more tumblers or a bigger box or something else), you can modify the file in this thing and export the STLs.

title: Belt/Disc Sander Dust Port adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a dust port adapter for the Central Machinery (Harbor Freight) combination 6" disc sander and 4"x36" belt sander, model #97181 (or similar).
For some reason, this sander doesn't come with an easy way to get the dust out.
It has two dust ports:

  • Disc: 19mm (3/4") OD
  • Belt: 40mm OD

This adapter connects to a 308mm long piece of 3/4" ID flexible tubing that goes to the disc dust port, and to a 2 1/4" shop vacuum hose.

All three pieces can be printed at once on my 230mm x 155mm Flashforge Creator Pro bed.
I printed them in ABS,

The bottom piece has a couple of very small holes where some STL fixup happened; I just put some hot-melt glue over these so they wouldn't make noise.

The 3mm holes around the perimeter of the adapter printed a bit too small for me to use 3mm hardware, but I drilled them out using a 3mm bit and used some 3mm x 11mm pins that I had to help align the parts while I glued them together. You could also probably use screws (3mm or #4) in these holes.

title: Thanos (Avengers: Infinity War version)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Can't wait for the upcoming Avengers movie? Well at least you can print Thanos in super high quality (and i think it's the most accurate version to the released trailer at this time). The model height is 30cm, but you can scale it down of course, if your printer does not allow this size. But keep in mind, bigger = better looking. I choose some design decision in favor of 3D printing, instead of better looking, for example the top facing flat area at the bottom (i saw, printers can't handle well textured flat area facing up). There could be some design improvements, maybe you can suggest, if you have some. I did not pay big attention to the armor, which has an unimpressive design and was not worth to recreate for me. So, sorry if you aren't satisfied with it. I myself did not test it, but from my experience, it should not have any problem. The mesh is created from scratch, water tight and a single object. Please keep in mind, this design is non-commercial and specially non-derivative. Happy printing.

title: QuickyBot - Small robot based on an arduino Nano board whith bluetooth and ultrasonic sensor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://youtu.be/u3WydDwLPMA

QuickyBot is a small development platform for learning arduino programming.

It is based on a Nano arduino card.
It has an ultrasonic distance sensor hc-sr04 to apprehend its environment.
It communicates via bluetooth using a HC-06 card.
It is powered by a 850 mAh LiPo battery.
Its two-wheel drive is powered by two micorservos 9g TowerPro SG90 modified for continuous rotation.

Here are links for modifying servos:

  • http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Make-a-TowerPro-Micro-Servo-Spin-360/
  • https://learn.adafruit.com/modifying-servos-for-continuous-rotation/overview

QuickyBot can be printed quickly and easily. It is made without much parts and can be made by beginners.
Only the upper shell requires the use of supports during printing.
(I modeled two upper shells because ultrasonic sensors may have slightly different dimensions depending on the manufacturer)

List of pieces :

1 Nano arduino card
1 ultrasonic sensor hc-sr04
1 bluetooth HC-06 card
1 LiPo battery 850mAh
1 DCDC Boost converter 0.9v/5v -> 5v 600mA
1 micro switch
1 female JST socket
2 microservo 9g TowerPro SG90
2 resistors 2.2k
2 screws 2,5X20
2 screws 2,5X25
2 ball bearing 3x8x4 693ZZ
1 screw 2,5X12 (or 2,5X15)

The electronic part is minimalist and simple to assemble according to the wiring diagram that I give you.

Be free to contact me if you encounter a difficulty to build your QuickyBot and give me a tip if you like my work :)

If you want, I made small arduino programs to start (calibrate the servos to find the complete stopping position of the wheels, change the name of the bluetooth card, control the QuickyBot by bluetooth or let it move in autonomous mode ...) and I also created a minimalist application for android smartphones to remotely control QuickyBots ...

FRENCH :

QuickyBot est une petite plateforme de développement pour l'apprentissage de la programmation sur arduino.

Il est basé sur une carte arduino Nano.
Il possède un capteur de distance ultrason hc-sr04 pour appréhender son environnement.
Il communique par bluetooth grâce à une carte HC-06.
Il est alimenté par une batterie LiPo 850 mAh.
Ses deux roues motrices sont actionnées par deux micorservos 9g TowerPro SG90 modifiés pour la rotation continue.

Voici des liens pour la modification des servos :

  • http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Make-a-TowerPro-Micro-Servo-Spin-360/
  • https://learn.adafruit.com/modifying-servos-for-continuous-rotation/overview

QuickyBot peut s'imprimer rapidement et simplement. Il est constitué de peux de pièces et peux être fabriqué par des débutants.
Seule la coque supérieure nécessite l'utilisation de supports au cours de l'impression.
(J'ai modélisé deux coques supérieures car les capteurs ultrason peuvent avoir des dimensions légèrement différentes selon les fabricants)

Liste des pièces :

  • 1 carte arduino Nano
  • 1 capteur ultrason hc-sr04
  • 1 carte bluetooth HC-06
  • 1 batterie LiPo 850mAh
  • 1 Convertisseur boost DCDC 0.9v/5v -> 5v 600mA
  • 1 micro interrupteur
  • 1 prise JST femelle
  • 2 microservo 9g TowerPro SG90
  • 2 résistances 2.2k
  • 2 vis 2,5X20
  • 2 vis 2,5X25
  • 2 roulement à billes 3x8x4 693ZZ
  • 1 vis 2,5X12 (ou 2,5X15)

La partie électronique est minimaliste et simple à assembler en suivant le schéma de câblage que je vous donne.

N'hésitez pas à me contacter si vous rencontrez une difficulté pour construire votre QuickyBot et pensez à me laisser un tips si aimez mon travail :)

Pour ceux que ça intéresse, j'ai fait des petits programmes arduino pour débuter (étalonner les servos pour trouver la position d’arrêt complet des roues, changer le nom de la carte bluetooth, piloter le QuickyBot par bluetooth ou le laisser évoluer en mode autonome...) et j'ai aussi créé une application minimaliste pour les smartphones android afin de commander à distance les QuickyBots...

title: Delta 28-160 10in Band Saw Trunnion Replacement Part 5140040-43
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An attempt at a replacement trunnion for the Delta 28-160 10" Bench Band Saw - Part Number 5140040-43 (discontinued.)

I made some changes to the design of the part to account for it being printed in plastic and not cast aluminum, including thickening some features. Longer fasteners may be required to attach to the table. There is still more play in the table than I'd like, which could be corrected through printing in a more rigid material (so far I have only tried PLA.)

The tolerances in the channels for angle adjustment are a bit tight, but functional in my print. I have included the Autodesk Inventor part file (IPT) as well as the STL in case anyone would like to improve on what I started.

Use your own best judgement when printing and using this part - work safe!

Delta 10" Bench Band Saw Model 28-160 Instruction Manual

description.text:
Greetings and Salutations fellow adventurers!

Please Note that the photos showcase the old prototype of the design which featured numerous errors resulting in warping, and layering. The released version should be smooth and stable.

In light of beginning a new D&D campaign, I came to a sudden conclusion upon catching that tabletop bug. "I MUST PRINT ALL THE THINGS".

After calming myself down over a glass of tea and a bucket of donuts, I realized that 1. Most designs I found online didn't quite suit my taste or needs, and 2. Ain't nobody got time to design and print everything. And thus, this project was born.

So what is it exactly? Is it a dice box for storing your dice? Is it a dice Tray for rolling dice? Will it likely cause me to expend all of my money on filament so that I may print boxes for all my friends?

The Answer is Yes!

Introducing the "Dice Box/ Tray/ Thing" v.1.x!

Print today and enjoy all of it's glorious features, such as:

  • Ample room for rolling all of your favorite dice! (and that one you stole from Tim)
  • A fabulous dice compartment for holding up to 5 sets of dice`! (That's one more whole set than 4!)
  • A decorative compartment cover for really showcasing your inner you!
  • A drawer built into the side allowing you to smuggle all sorts of knickknacks into your gaming sessions``! Or use it for pencils. Most likely pencils.

Although future designs are almost certainty going to be released going forward, I highly encourage you to comment any suggestions or issues you may have so that I may promptly and eloquently ignore them. Not really though, that would be rude.

Download, Enjoy, and Adventure on my friends!

If you do enjoy what I have procured, consider leaving a tip. Any amount helps, and will only help further inflate my ego to disastrous proportions. In turn, I will be obliged to continue creating and submitting my designs mostly free of charge.

` Dice storage based off 5 sets of standard sized dice. Larger or specialty dice may not properly fit, and may require adjustment. Quick Fix: Scale up box Top Half in the Z (Vertical) Direction ONLY. May result in unwanted gawking at your unnecessarily large box. You've been warned.

`` I do not condone the smuggling of unknown objects into your gaming sessions. If you do not heed my advice, the DM might inflict an untimely demise for your character. DMs: If you are reading this, The player's choice to bring in prohibited items was neither condoned by me or mine. If you wish to punish the unruly player, might I suggest death by rabid chicken.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15% - 20%

Notes:

  • SUPPORTS RECOMMENDED on the storage tray as the handle has a pretty steep overhang. All other parts should print fine without them.

  • Pending your printer's printable area, box scaling may need to be altered to fit. Remember to alter all parts to the same scaling percentages as failure to do so may result in a deformed monstrosity. And neither of us want that.

  • I recommend using Wood filament as it provides the most traditional look and feel, though any filament should work in theory. It has the added bonus of allowing layer lines to look like layers in the wood, which helps hide the fact that it was 3d printed.

Assembly/Cleanup

So you've printed your box and want to know what to do next. In only a few easy steps you can have your box up and running and ready to hold all Most A good portion of your glorious dice!

  • (OPTIONAL) For a slightly stiffer side drawer, consider gluing down some felt on the bottom drawer cavity. This might help prevent unwanted drawer slippage and will help keep things secure during travel.

  • Line the bottom half of the box with glue, making sure to place some extra on top of each of the registration pegs (the 2 cylinders and the L in the corners).

  • Line up the top half, and push firmly down, ensuring both halves are aligned. There's is a bit of 'wiggle room' on the pegs, so you may have to manually align the box to it's final location.

  • After properly aligning, clamp down both halves with steady and even pressure to ensure proper adhesion.

  • Sand away rough edges and excess glue, making sure to clean off the side tray in order to ensure smooth movement.

  • Ensure drawer slides smoothly yet securely, adding additional felt to the bottom of the drawer as needed.

  • Place dice into dice cavity, and cover with your choice of insert.

Enjoy!

Version 1.0 [January 3rd, 2018]
  • Uploaded design to Thingiverse
Version 1.1 [January 4th, 2018]

  • Deepened Dice cavity allowing for slightly larger dice. Will likely make accommodations for larger dice in future designs

  • Cleaned up and fixed Design Plate sizing

  • Published design to the masses
Version 1.2 [January 5th, 2018]
  • Lengthened front pegs and registration holes to help prevent breakage after printing [only applies to unsectioned version]
  • Added Sectioned version for smaller print beds due to popular request. Largest dimension is ~112mm. If needed, Scaling down to 100mm shouldn't cause issues as long as everything is scaled to the same percentage.
  • Word of Caution Plate Top and Bottom are slightly different dimensions. Printing 2 of the same might result in either a too loose or too tight top plate
  • Recommended that you assemble in order of large sections -
    • Assemble 6 box bottom pieces together with glue. Gluing all 6 pieces at once is recommended to help ensure proper alignment between all the parts
    • Repeat process for 6 box top pieces and 4 tray bottom pieces
    • Print plate ends and your choice of plate body. Align and glue
    • Glue box top to box bottom, ensuring alignment
    • Clean up, and enjoy!
Version 1.2.2 [January 13th, 2018]
  • Changed side logo into engraving. Should help print quality on most printers

title: Upper platform for the TUSH spool holder

description.text:
My quest for the perfect spool has come to the end. The TUSH spool holder, placed in the right point, offers the perfect entry angle and the filament runs smoothly.
I own a p3Steel v4, a kind of version of Prusa i3 (but I truly think this stuff would fit other printers). The LCD is placed up, so I needed something where the TUSH could stand. I made the platform with Tinkercad, so you can edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iyHHLJg4m1r
Notice that the platform comes with a ribbon, so the TUSH can't move forwards.

You will need 4x M8 nuts and 2x M8 rod screws of ~10 cm if you want to attach the platform to the frame. For this purpose, I printed a couple of clips from thing 414963 by Fabsterdam.

Happy printing!

description.text:
A trophy I made for an "angular fixit week" to give out to the top fixers.

The trophy is based on the angular-logo-as-a-cube school of thought, rather than the angular-logo-as-a-shield camp ;P ! Therefore, the center of the trophy ring is a partially 3d-projected cube. This gives it the illusion of perspective when viewed from the right angle, just like angular logo itself does. The code is not perfectly clear, but, you may be interested in reading through it or copying the concept in your own designs!

I suggest you print it in two parts, especially if you can print multiple top pieces at once. That will help with the overhang. They should fit together afterwards. However, you can certainly try to print in one go.

Most everything is allowed to be customized in the "advanced" tab in the customizer, but beware of dragons. I didn't really design that stuff to be customized.

title: Strain Relief for Anycubic Kossel Linear (Remix)

description.text:
This is a remix of Kiolia's strain relief, which I've modified to suit the Anycubic Linear. The original was designed for the XL and wouldn't fit my printer because my extruder stands proud of the top surface of the effector by 2mm, so this remix has a larger 16mm diameter cutout to clear the top of the extruder.

If you want to check compatibility before printing this, the four mount holes for my extruder are spaced at 12mm x 22mm, and I measured the extruder diameter at 15.95mm.

Thanks to Kiolia for the original design!

description.text:
This is a model of the Sputnik 1, worlds first satellite launched by the Soviet Union on the 4th of October 1957. It was nothing more than a metal ball with for radio antennas that broadcasted radio signals back to earth that gave information about the ionosphere. The satellite was simple, but is commonly thought of as the satellite that set of the space race.

This model was inspired by the works of Noah Li-Leger, who made a fantastic model of voyager one (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2556130).

description.text:
A simple model of the Halo Magnum Pistol, used in Halo 3 and Halo Reach (I think). The slide and magazine are meant to be movable as I plan to add springs to hold the slide in place and the magazine is to be held by magnets.

Use the HandleTrigger.stl as the base component, then attach all other parts to it.

This is still a work in progress.

Here is the reference picture I used:

https://www.halopedia.org/images/7/72/HReach-M6GMagnumPistol-LeftSide.png

Ideally I'd like to add the little details later on, but for now I am quite happy with the way it turned out.

title: Dial Indicator Mount (Bed Leveling)  for Monoprice Select Mini, Chinese or Harbor Freight Dial

description.text:
Other hardware required:

6mm or SAE almost-equivalent bolt and nut.

Using paxamime's excellent original dial indicator gauge mounts as a base I've modified them to fit a Harbor Freight or Chinese equivalent dial indicator gauge. It's one of the more common models of digital dial indicator to be found.

Two modifications are also included. It has been modified to fit over the stock stamped steel axis stiffener and snugs up against it nicely.

The other modification is for the dial to mount directly to the piece not sandwiched in-between two pieces of plastic. While that did look neat it made printing the part without supports a non-starter for me.

My own printer with an E3D hot-end requires the zero offset version of the mount.

title: Support WG2 Feiyu pour harnais - Chest mount Harness - Gopro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Le syteme fournis avec le Gimball ne convenait pas pour mon usage ( snowboard ) en raison de son porte a faux et du faible diamètre.
Je voulais plus d'appuis et simple a mettre en oeuvre, mais sur la V1 l'ergot sautait à la separation du support - WG2.
Sur la V2 j'ai fait un ergot mobile d'abord court pour ne pas gener le clipsage sur le harnais mais finalement la tenue n'etait pas terrible. Du coup j'ai fait un ergot fileter long qui n'autorise pas le clipsage avant le montage mais qui en même temps empeche le devissage une fois en place.
Alors quitte à mettre une vis autant le faire avec une vis au bon diamètre et pas Kodak.

The system provided with the Gimball was not suitable for my use (snowboard) because of its overhang and small diameter.
I wanted more support and simple to implement, but on the V1 the lug cracked to the separation of the support - WG2.
On the V2 I made a first short mobile lug for clipping on the harness but finally it was not terrible. So I made a long threaded lug that does not allow clipping before assembly but at the same time prevents the unscrewing once in place.
So leave to put a screw as much with a screw to the correct Kodak diameter

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Yes

Notes:

Les supports sont nécessaire même pour la vis.
Pour une question de rigidité de celle ci, il faut absolument l'imprimer soit à l'horizontal soit incliner.
Pour le support V1 l'ergot du petit coté à casser au démontage même sur le deuxième print a 100% d'infill sur leur zone

The supports are necessary even for the screw.
For a question of rigidity of this one, it is absolutely necessary to print it either horizontally or to incline.
For the support V1 the small side pin breaked at dismounting even on the second print at 100% Infill on their area.

description.text:
Update: I added a one piece bracket that has been cleaned up a bit. Having the split clamp did not seem to give any huge advantage.

I'm DIY'ing a mount for my kayak fish finder transducer. This clamp is intended to hold 1/2" schedule 40 electrical conduit available at Lowes or Home Depot in your Kayak's gear track, I'm using a 90 degree curved piece and a short extension for the transducer arm.

The mount is designed to allow for a small rubber strip to be glued to the bottom of the clamp to act as friction material for the PVC while allowing the transducer to pivot if you hit an obstacle. I'm going to use a standard stainless steel 1/4 bolt on one side and a stainless bolt with an adjustment knob on the other so I can easily swing the transducer up and out of the way when coming ashore.

author: frederique555

description.text: California Riverside Mission Inn bell

There is nothing that can't be re-engineered to make it a lot more complicated.

ValarmLLC's terminal connector was a great starting point, but I needed to make some modifications to have 8 terminals, two rows, and a space underneath to jumper the terminals together into bus bars.

My design is printed in multiple parts, depending on what you need

  • Single row with slide-on post cover that snaps into place
  • Dual row, where you print two of the slide-on post covers
  • Single or dual row base that snaps on, optional, if you need protection from shorts on the surface you are mounting to.

To make this a bus bar rather than just post connectors, jumper the connections together underneath as needed with wire.

Like in the original, it's sized for #6-32 screws and hex nuts, and length should be around 3/8". Washers are a good idea as well, although technically not required. #6 sheet metal or similar screws should work for the mounting points.

Thing is designed not to need supports when printing. I used PETG, but I don't see why PLA or ABS shouldn't also work just fine.

The first object I have ever created intended for 3D printing. The PokeBall is a very simple model and features a hinge so that the ball can actually open and close.

The middle piece should attach to the top piece (i.e. the middle piece should not be attached to the bottom piece for Pokemon anime correctness)
Create parametric dovetail. Your printing area is too small ? No problem, cut your piece and reassemble it ! Updated version : https://github.com/hugokernel/OpenSCAD_Dovetail

Example : dim = [20, 60, 5];
clear = 0.3; /**
  • [x, y, z]
    • x : Teeth count
    • y : Teeth height
    • z : Teeth Clearance
      */
      teeth = [3, 4, clear];
    • intersection() {
    cube(size = dim, center = true);
    cutter([0, -10, 0], dim, teeth, true);
    }

description.text: I added a small stand to put in a sirringe in an upright position to tare the scale.

Finally, a high-end 3D model of a PS4 aimstick. With these sticks you can improve your aim and lighten your grip on FPS and racing games!

It's super easy:
Choose your desired profile
Choose your desired height (6.5mm - 8.0mm - 9.5mm)
Print the bottom part
Screw them with the built-in thread!

DON'T FORGET TO READ THE INSTRUCTIONS! :)

FEEDBACK:
Is your aimstick loose? Does it twist? Do you have trouble printing? Do you think one of the designs is flawed? Do you think you have a 'brilliant idea' for another one?
!! Please let me know !!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

50 - 80 microns

Infill:

20%

Notes:

BOTTOM:
Ensure to rotate the model 180° after downloading, it will be printable without supports!
Print the outer walls slowly (15-25mm/s). This, in combination with the layer height, ensures it is strong enough and good enough quality for the thread!

IF you have the option, use a 0.25mm nozzle to get a post-process free finish!

TOP(s):
Print these with a 85° overhang setting! This ensures the flat part is supported, while the rest is the highest quality possible. Don't worry, you will screw most of it to the bottom part anyways!

BOTH:
If you have the option to perform a 'horizontal expansion initial layer', do so. If using Cura, set it to -0.2mm. This ensures both thread's won't be over-extruded, and twist smoothly.

Step 1: Remove strings/blobs from BOTTOM part.

The BOTTOM part has quite some retraction because of the upright 'feet'. If there was any stringing, remove it carefully to protect your controller from being damaged by sharp edges!

Step 2: TWIST!

Twist the BOTTOM part on the TOP part. The thread should catch quite easy and you should be able to screw it as thight as you can. You don't want it to come loose mid-game!

Onshape

...

description.text: Polski Fiat 621 - 1:72

This is the SnowSpinner a print in place bearing snowflake built with BlocksCAD software. This is the first thing I ever created with the BlocksCAD software. Attached is my xml "block" file that shows how I build this.

Need to print this with support touching build plate turned on.

I printed mine with a 0.2mm layer height and a 50% infill with PLA. This took about 2 hours to print.

Introduction, Overview This is a print in place, snowflake bearing spinner. In order to complete this project the student has will understand designing mechanical clearance gaps and blocking out loop structures in pseudo code. Mechanical Modification:
During going through this project the students should be encouraged to change the number of balls in the bearing. The students can also play with the ball size and clearance values. Sample Test Question 1
When printing, how much of the BB needs to be truncated to print correctly? Sample Test Question 2
How many BB's are needed to run the bearing smoothly? Sample Test Question 3
How small can you print this out and still have the bearing work? Artistic Modification:
This framework also allows students to use the peudocode blocking loops to modify the color, and snowflake design.
Artistic students should be encouraged to play with mathematically derived designs such as fractals or other repeatable structures. Sample Test Question 4
How many branches of a snowflake can you fit? Sample Test Question 5
Can you derive the trigonometric relationship for the snow flake branches for a centered cube transform? Sample Test Question 6
How complex of a structure can you build off the top of the inner race?
45 min

description.text:
I made this so that I can give this as a present to nieces and nephews. The other light switch plates take a long time to print out >14 hours. This light switch plate takes about 4.5 hours with a 0.2mm layer and 55% fill density.

Three of these should fit side to side on a 3 light switch plate. (Comment if you try it out please!)

2 should fit side to side on a two light switch plate.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

55%

Notes:

I printed it out using Brim and supports touching the build plates. It doesn't need support everywhere to print out correclty.

You might need to clean up the snap fit with an exacto knife.

Slide it on

To install:

Cut off the Brim. Note* the back snap support is the same thickness as the brim so be careful when removing it. I cut the brim off with a scissor.

Remove the supports

Snap gear into place and slide the pinion into place.

TURN OFF THE POWER TO THE LIGHT SWITCH.

Remove the current light switch plate
Slide the fixture onto the existing light switch plate.
Put the plate back on the wall.

Turn the power back on.

title: Bitcoin Ethereum Cryptocurrency Trezor Seed Vault

description.text:
This is a master seed vault for your Trezor or other cryptocurrency seeds. Really, you can put anything you want in here. It's meant to be a sealed container that must be broken to be opened, so you know if it's been tampered with.

To use this:

  1. Print out just high enough for what you want to put inside.
  2. Pause print
  3. Optionally raise the print head to allow access to the interior
  4. Insert seed key or other material
  5. Optionally lower print head
  6. Resume print

If and when you need access to the contents, crack open the vault and retrieve your keys. While it won't keep anyone out, it will let you know if anyone has seen your master seed and it will prevent casual tampering.

For added security, you could give this a quick acetone bath, assuming you were printing in ABS, to smooth it out and make it a bit stronger.

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

I designed this to mount a set of gears on the wall and have them spin together.

Non-3D printed parts needed:
-Adhesive to mount items (command strips recommended)
-Standard skateboard bearing

Mounting to the wall

Put the bearing in the piece with the hole in the middle. This should be a snug fit.

Attach the piece with the bearing to the wall and the flat surface of the piece with the peg to the item you want to spin on the wall. I recommend command strips, but a strong adhesive of any kind should work.

Insert the peg of the item to spin in the bearing and now the item should be able to spin on the wall.

description.text:
All credit goes to the original: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1786543

My sensor did not fire when I removed the filament. With this deeper holder, it does.

The original description:

This little piece of plastic will with an optical endstop and octoprint combined save you from failed prints when you run out of filament :-)

Remixed the original to be able to use a ziptie for fasteing. (As i did not have fitting screws)

Also slimmed it down a bit to use it with my boden holder and it attaches nicely to my i3 mk2.

Octoprint: http://octoprint.org/
Filament Plugin:https://github.com/MoonshineSG/OctoPrint-Filament

Pi Wireing: https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/usage/gpio/
Example Wireing:
G - ground --> Ground on the Pi
S - signal --> GPIO 14
V - volt --> 5 V on the Pi

Test the right value for the sensor:
http://raspi.tv/2013/rpi-gpio-basics-6-using-inputs-and-outputs-together-with-rpi-gpio-pull-ups-and-pull-downs

Write the right value into octoprint config.

Please post your makes :-)

print_settings.Notes:: Also depending on how hard you're pushing your first layer, you may have some "elephant footing" and may need to clean up the curves at the bottom of the base. You can also experiment with horizontal expansion settings in cura that try to compensate for this. I print my first layer at a snails pace of 6mms and 6mms travel speed and default 60/70 the rest of the way. Your first layer is most important in a print, if you lay down your first layer cleanly, the rest will look great, otherwise you will have gaps and unevenness. Printing a first layer fast also tends to create supports that are unreliable and break off during the rest of the print and screw holes that peel up and stick to the nozzle. Trust me, you do not want to rush with the foundation of your print, print the first layer nice and slow and you'll be happy with the results

Notes:

Main supports were easy to remove, followed by briefly burning off the white marks with bic lighter. Supports in the speaker hole were a little bit of an effort, but overall came out cleanly. I used a small drill bit and a small hex head screwdriver to clean those out along with a pair of needle nose pliers to get out the rest

I snipped off dust cover with a pair of scissors. It should work with it attached but makes case a pain to dock. It took a few tries to get the right length of cable sticking out so that it plugs in easily. I noticed it works well if you push through the cable, plug your phone in, then put phone into dock, and then put in a little extra underneath and route cable through the cutout at base

Also depending on how hard you're pushing your first layer, you may have some "elephant footing" and may need to clean up the curves at the bottom of the base. You can also experiment with horizontal expansion settings in cura that try to compensate for this. I print my first layer at a snails pace of 6mms and 6mms travel speed and default 60/70 the rest of the way. Your first layer is most important in a print, if you lay down your first layer cleanly, the rest will look great, otherwise you will have gaps and unevenness. Printing a first layer fast also tends to create supports that are unreliable and break off during the rest of the print and screw holes that peel up and stick to the nozzle. Trust me, you do not want to rush with the foundation of your print, print the first layer nice and slow and you'll be happy with the results

title: Simple N64 Wall Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ever wanted to mount your N64 to a wall? Whether just for storage or for permanent use? Try this wall mount I designed for my little Nintendo console collection.

About:
The device's weight is carried by the two cones and the clamp on top prevents it from falling off.
The big curved shape is there to support the lower part of the console.

Use whatever screw type (and maybe wall plugs) that fit your wall the best. I'm not responsible if your N64 falls off and gets damaged.

How to use:
To place the N64 on the mount, first put the hole on the upper rear of the console onto the rear cone of the mount. Then push upwards to the wall until the front cone is reached. The clamp should now snap (and hopefully not break) and hold it in place.

Other mounts for Nintendo consoles I designed:

  • Simple N64 Wall Mount
  • Simple GameCube Wall Mount
  • Wii Wall Mount

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The STL file is for mounting the N64 on a left wall (from front view). For right walls (like in my images), just mirror the model on the x or y axis.

Print with the wall facing part down and generate supports for the clamp.

Printed with a 0.4mm nozzle in PLA with 3 outlines. With these settings the clamp is still bendable enough.
The screw holes in this model are for 3mm screws with a countersunk head.

title: Travel Guitar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is just a travel (small) guitar that I made to be easy to carry to band practices. This is swapped from what you generally see in a guitar, with the tuners at the bottom and the strings attaching at the top. There are two versions, one of which is sliced to fit on a 170 mm by 170 mm space, but it can also fit on smaller. The other version is not cut at all. One file is the body of the guitar and the other is the neck. The fret board goes up to 12th fret. There is a hole in the neck where you can reinforce it. I just put a metal ruler there and it works just fine. I recommend using nylon strings, as they take less pressure and make the guitar much harder to bend.

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Parametric Involute  Bevel and Spur Gears

description.text:
This is a parametric robotic claw that I have designed. The purpose is to allow the claw design to accommodate a variety of objects to lift. The example I have built has a reduction gear stage to increase the servo power and to widen the profile allowing the claw to grip cubic blocks of 100mm edges. The SCAD design allows selection of the number of gear stages, length of the arms, beam thickness, as well as a few other parameters. With this design you can generate any claw your robot could need. Am example of the claw operating can be seen here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ribNNGnRoTQ and here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hxc98augCaA

1) Modify the object you want to size against
2) Change settings to customise your claw until correctly sized
3) Customise the print_plate module to build for printing
4) Print and assemble the claw Notes:
1) I still need to modify the single stage servo positioning on the plate and driven gear
2) The servo mount is for a med servo I had for a sparkfun claw, this may need to be modified for your design
3) the gears can be fixed together with 3mm PLA filiment
4) you may need to adjust Gear_Play depending on the quality of your printer

description.text:
I tried the print in place bearing from bribro12 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2349065), but on smaller bearings like skateboard size, I found the rollers twisted out of place and jammed up. Instead I moved the fat parts to the outside and that keeps them in line.This also seems to make them easier to free up after printing.

I uploaded 3 popular sizes. The larger two print pretty cleanly from me. The small one needs a little care to work in after printing. Don't expect these to be a replacement for real bearings, but they are good enough for mission critical components such as a gimbal stabilized beer holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2727133)

Update 1/19/18: So I uploaded this because I thought a few people would have a passing curiosity. It got more hits in the first few hours than all of my useful things put together. I tweaked a few dimensions, put a chamfer on the outside so you don't usually need a raft to print and provided more clearance in the center of the rollers so they ride on the outside. I added these as mk2 designs. Their motion is a little sloppier, but they are easier to print and get working. Also see a filament spool holder using these I added here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2763126

Update 1/26/18: This silly thing continues to be rather popular. Since people are starting to make remixes with the 608zz bearing, while others are having trouble printing it (either falling apart or coming out frozen up), I added a series of 608s. Loose (0.35mm clearance), Standard (0.30mm), Tight (0.25) and Extra Tight (0.20mm). Also a Standard with more rollers that helps with thrust loads. I can print all of these in PLA; the loose one come off the print bed working but can fall apart, the extra tight one needs a tool to be broken free but then works the best. Printing in ABS or PETG won't work with the loose one, it will fall right apart. If you want to tinker more, the Fusion 360 source as well as a dozen CAD formats are available here: http://a360.co/2ndT5VB. In Fusion 360, open the sketch and fill in the inner/outer diameter and height for the bearing you need; set a starting race thickness of about 1.5mm; add as many rollers as will fit (with the parameter page or by editing the pattern tool on the main page); finally fine tune the clearance between rollers by adjusting the race thickness.

comments.text:
this bearing should not work correctly. The inner ring has two different outer diameters and that makes that these diameters do have different speeds. (mm/sec or inch/sec) The rollers do have also different outer diameters with different speeds.
For that reason, per definition there will be high friction between the barrel rollers and inner/outer ring.
A ball bearing could be discussed in the same way but there we assume that there is only point contact and friction will be a lot less.
Printing ball bearings is not that difficult even when the balls are floating a little above the print bed. I can explain why but SIMPLIFY3D explains it perfectly in one of there YouTube lessons.
But really thanks for sharing, it did trigger something else in my mind. :-)
comments.author: evandene

comments.text:
Evandene,
You are 100% right. If both the wide and the narrow part of the roller contacts the races it will bind up. The taper angle on the races is slightly less than the roller so it should only hit on the fat ends. This might need some more tweaking to assure it happens on the printed result. I find that the print oozes out more on inside curves than outside curves.
comments.author: evandene

comments.text: Try a Barrel Bearing design. The barrel radius needs to be 5 mm less as the radius from inner and outer ring. Than again you have point contact.

description.text:
Made them for for hanging your mops and brooms and small vacuum sweepers in my laundry utility closet. II use it for the Swiffer, a dust mop, and a small dirt devil vac (a dust buster on a stick). Use double sided tape to mount (~3" x 0.75"), especially the 3M stuff meant for painted drywall. There are several versions, one has a 1/16" recess for thick double-sided tape to keep the part close to flush. I ended up using the "no recess" version with the 3M wall tape and works great so far. The "wide version" is basically version 2 and better for things that have a big hole through the handle instead of a ring or separate loop like the swiffer.

The part can be printed in PLA with the wall facing side on the printer bed. Makes for a nice smooth surface for the tape but is still plenty strong for whatever you plan to hook it onto. I could not break off the hook from the base.

This is the enclosure for my 3D Scanner's controller:

http://pulsar124.wikia.com/wiki/3D_Scanner

The 3D Scanner slowly rotates a platform with the object to scan while regularly triggering the photocamera's shutter and optionally external flashes. It is based on Arduino Nano. It has a small display and a 4x4 keypad allowing you to modify the parameters. It is optimized for Canon DSLRs (making use of the electronic shutter feature of Magic Lantern firmware - meaning the mechanical shutter will not wear off) but can be easily adopted for any other camera which shutter can be triggered from a wired controller. One still needs photogrammetry software to make a 3D model of your object from a bunch of photos (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_photogrammetry_software for a comprehensive list).

The controller is specifically designed for the PCB of my design. (The PCB Gerbers files are provided on the wikia page above.)

I printed the two parts (top and bottom) in ABS, with no support or brim/raft.

title: Universal Filament Spool Hub
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Universal Filament Spool Hub (Uholder1.stl and Uholder2.stl ) is designed to reduce friction of the spool rotation. Excessive friction can lower the quality of the print. There were following design priorities:

  • minimal friction;
  • accommodate variety of spool widths and hole diameters;
  • hub shouldn't extend the width of the spool too much (to fit more spools into container);
  • easy, fast, secure lock/unlock on the spool (breech-lock is used);
  • can be used on a printer or within a container;
  • easy to build, minimal number of parts;
  • minimum amount of plastic;
  • no support is required (disable it);

Using bearings was deemed unnecessary as the friction of PLA and 6mm metal rod is very low.

Rod holders (AxelHolder.stl) for Original Prusa printers and containers (BarHolder1.stl and BarHolder2.stl) are included.

AxelHolder.stl - use a file to fit it to the Prusa spool holders.

BarHolder1.stl and BarHolder2.stl account for the tilt of the sides of the container and allow putting the container on the side. Double sided mounting tape is used to attach holders to the container sides.

6mm metal rods without threads are available on ebay.

Your feedback is welcome!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

PLA was used. Support should be disabled for all parts, but AxelHolder.stl.

Let the bed cool down after printing before removing the printed part. The print will bend if you don't do that!

Let two parts of the spool hub to break in without a spool. Some force may be used to connect/disconnect them initially.

remixed_from.title: Toyota 4 Cylinder Engine 22RE, Complete working model

description.text:
If you, like me, didn't print and assemble the crankshaft the perfect way, chances are you will experience a lot of resistance when turning it(and no way a small DC motor can drive it). This attachment allows you to break in the engine with a drill.

Simply attach a drill to it and give it a good 30 seconds to 1 minute run. The PLA parts will heat up quickly and smooth out all the friction points(you will know it when you starts to smell some unpleasant smell). Of course you will need to be able to turn it by hand in order to apply this mod.

The hex end is created by heating up a 12mm nut bit set and press it in. Having fun 3d printing

description.text: I initially printed and used @donnyb99's Hotend Cable Management hook. But having that mounted made it tough for my big fingers to work the extruder handle. So I next looked for an extension for the handle and found @Coolcrawler_'s extended extruder arm. But I still wanted some way to protect the filament from the Z-axis screw, so I remixed them all together and added a soda-straw'like protrusion to keep the filament safe as it passes the Z-Axis screw. It's mounted and working great for me. I hope someone else finds it useful. It's my first Thing™!

author: ekaiser1901

description.text:
Razor blade holder for scraping glue etc off your print bed. Print the holder on its side with supports. This will allow for most precise fitting of the razor.

Print the cap on its end for best quality.

I printed in two different colors, black for the bottom and blue for the top. Honey Bees see a different color spectrum than humans. Google around for the pictures of what flowers look like to a honey bee.

Honey Bees cannot see red, so I do not recommend printing in red. They seem to prefer colors that are closer to the UV spectrum, with UV absorbing colors being more attractive.

For the food, I take bottled water and mix in as much white sugar as possible. If you take a standard water bottle half full with the filtered water, add sugar until the bottle is over 3/4ths full and shake vigorously. If the water is warmed up the sugar will dilute into the water easier.

The sweeter the mix is, the less attractive it will be to wasps. Yellowjackets and wasps typically prefer savory flavors, which explains why I always see them near the trash can or even eating meat.

I start by filling the feeder up to the top of the ridges.

I plan to conduct further experiments to come up with a more ergonomic feeding apparatus for the Bees. I would also like to explore the possibility of adding some threads into the center so a water bottle can be screwed in for extended feeding.

remixed_from.author: spectre03cobra
remixed_from.title: IH Milling mahcine (Rung Fu etc) Spindle wrench

description.text: Once I started using my basic draw nut wrench along with spectre03cobra's spindle wrench I immediately thought there must be a better way to do this. Why go through the 5 seconds worth of effort to flip open the top when there's that hole there that you can go through? My next thought was "I'm definitely going to get distracted and leave a wrench connected to the draw nut sticking out of the cover, turn the mill on, and accidentally kill myself"...so, I made this nested round knob which does the same job with a much lower likelihood of killing me if I leave it on the spindle/nut and turn on the machine.

Print these as plated, standing on the tail. The angles are all configured to work this way without support. If you want the 45-degree overhang chamfers to look good, go with 0.2 or better resolution. If you don't mind a little surface imperfection, 0.3 works fine.

description.text:
I really like the Glowing Lithograph moons that I've seen a few people print and I wanted to make one into a desk lamp. I liked Brandonzhun's Glowing moon because it was split into 2 parts: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2531838

I printed just the top part of the moon and designed my lamp base to take the place of the bottom half. I drew thew up in Rhino 3D real quick, and wanted something pretty simple that I'd be able to print with one of my cool 16m Makerbox samples, I used Proto Pasta's Glitter filament here.

You can print this with no supports, and probably pretty much any layer height you want, I think I used .16mm or .2mm

I then used a small C7 light bulb socket/candelabra base I got from a local hardware/home improvement store: https://www.menards.com/main/lighting-ceiling-fans/lighting-hardware-accessories/kits-cleaners-accessories/patriot-lighting-snap-in-socket-cord-set-with-switch/p-1444429515492-c-7522.htm?tid=-2798504868495257948&ipos=1 and a .4w C7 LED bulb. I used some hot glue to glue the light socket it, its a little larger than the socket so the plug and switch will fit through.

If you are curious the I printed the Moon with Maker Geek's White hot white at .12mm layer height and 75mms because I didn't want the layer lines to stick out, I think it turned out great.

Feel free to print this Glowing Moon lamp base for yourself or as a gift, but please don't be selling them. If you really want to sell one or more holler at me and we'll work something out.
